questions.text: A child is able to copy a cross, tell stories, and go to the toilet alone. What is the probable age of the child as per the development attained?
questions.solution:
A child at 4 years

  • Gross motor: Hops on one foot, can go downstairs with alternate feet
  • Fine motor: Copies Cross, makes bridge with blocks
  • Social: Cooperative group play, goes to toilet alone
  • Language: Tells stories, says poem

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: 3 years
    • A 3-year-old can copy a circle, but not a cross.
    • Gross motor skills: Goes upstairs with alternating feet but not downstairs.
    • Social skills: Engages in parallel play rather than cooperative play.
    • Language skills: Can speak in short sentences, but telling structured stories is limited.
  • Choice C: 5 years
    • A 5-year-old can copy a square, which is more advanced than copying a cross.
    • Gross motor skills: Can skip and ride a bicycle.
    • Language skills: Can tell longer, more complex stories and may read simple words.
  • Choice D: 2 years
    • A 2-year-old can scribble but not copy specific shapes.
    • Social skills: Still in solitary play, may have toilet training initiated but not independent.
    • Language skills: Uses two-word phrases but does not tell structured stories.

Key Takeaway

  • A 4-year-old child can copy a cross, tell stories, and go to the toilet alone.
  • These skills align with the expected developmental milestones for this age.

questions.text: All of the following are included under diagnostic criteria of Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) except:
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition:

  1. Weight-for-height below-3 standard deviation (<-3SD) on the WHO Growth Standard; OR
  2. Presence of bipedal edema; OR
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) below 11.5 cm (age 6 mo or more)

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Weight for height (<-3SD on WHO Growth Standard) (Correct Criterion)
    • Weight-for-height is a key indicator of wasting (acute malnutrition).
    • A value below -3 SD on WHO growth charts is diagnostic of SAM.
  • Choice C: Pedal edema (Correct Criterion)
    • Bilateral pitting edema indicates nutritional edema (Kwashiorkor), a form of severe malnutrition.
    • It signifies protein-energy malnutrition even if weight-for-height is normal.
  • Choice D: MUAC < 11.5 cm (Correct Criterion)
    • MUAC < 11.5 cm is a simple and reliable indicator of SAM in children aged 6 months to 5 years.
    • It is widely used in community screening for malnutrition.

Key Takeaway

  • Height-for-age is used to assess chronic malnutrition (stunting), not SAM.
  • SAM diagnostic criteria:
    1. Weight-for-height < -3 SD on WHO Growth Standards.
    2. Bilateral pedal edema.
    3. MUAC < 11.5 cm (for children ≥6 months).

questions.text: A two-year-old baby presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding, as well as bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Lab investigations reveal normal prothrombin time, normal thrombin time, normal partial thromboplastin time, normal platelet count, and normal platelet function. Urea clot solubility testing is positive. What is the likely deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Factor XIII deficiency (Fibrin Stabilizing factor deficiency) affects cross linking of fibrin for clot stabilization. They presents with frequent bruising or hematoma. Rarely they bleed profusely.
  • All usual screening test of bleeding are normal. Urea clot solubility is delayed/positive.
  • Specific diagnosis needs level of Factor XIII.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Factor IX Deficiency (Hemophilia B)
    • Hemophilia B presents with prolonged aPTT, but in this case, aPTT is normal.
    • Typically causes deep tissue or joint bleeding, rather than mucosal/umbilical bleeding.
  • Choice B: Factor X Deficiency
    • Prolonged PT and aPTT are seen in Factor X deficiency, but this case has normal coagulation tests.
    • Presents with severe bleeding tendencies, including CNS and mucosal bleeding.
  • Choice C: Factor XII Deficiency
    • Factor XII deficiency prolongs aPTT but does not cause bleeding.
    • It is usually asymptomatic and detected incidentally in lab tests.

Key Takeaway

  • Factor XIII deficiency presents with delayed bleeding, umbilical stump bleeding, and mucosal bleeds despite normal coagulation tests.
  • The Urea Clot Solubility Test is positive, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates a primary failure of treatment in an admitted child with severe acute malnutrition?
A. Failure to regain appetite by day 4,
B. Failure to start losing edema by day 4,
C. Complete absence of edema by day 10,
D. Weight gain of less than 5 g/kg/day from day 20
questions.solution:
• Failure to regain appetite by day 4
  • Failure to start losing edema by day 4
  • Presence of edema on day 10
  • Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

Incorrect Choice Explanation

  • Choice D (Weight gain < 5 g/kg/day from day 20) is incorrect
    • The criterion states failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10, not from day 20.
    • Slow weight gain after day 20 indicates a secondary failure, not primary failure of treatment.

Key Takeaway

  • Primary failure in SAM treatment includes:
    • No appetite return by day 4
    • No edema reduction by day 4
    • Edema persisting on day 10
    • Weight gain < 5 g/kg/day by day 10

choices.text: Most of the children require phototherapy
It's a condition due to exclusive breastfeeding, the total bilirubin exceeding 10 mg/dl after 3-4 weeks of birth

questions.text: Which is a true statement about breast milk jaundice?
questions.solution:
• Approximately 2-4% of exclusively breastfed term babies have jaundice in excess of 10 mg/dL beyond 3rd-4th weeks of life.
  • A diagnosis of breast milk jaundice should be considered, if this is unconjugated (not staining nappies); and other causes for prolongation such as inadequate feeding, continuing haemolysis, extravasated blood, G6PD deficiency and hypothyroidism have been ruled out.
  • Mothers should be advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals and TSB levels usually decline over a period of time.
  • Some babies may require phototherapy.
  • Breastfeeding should not be stopped either for diagnosis or treatment of breast milk jaundice.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: "Most of the children require phototherapy"
    • Incorrect - While some babies may need phototherapy, most cases of BMJ do not require treatment, as bilirubin levels decline naturally over time.
  • Choice B: "Breastfeeding should not be continued"
    • Incorrect - Breastfeeding should always be continued, as stopping it is not necessary for diagnosis or treatment. Temporary interruption is not recommended.
  • Choice D: "Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia"
    • Incorrect - Breast milk jaundice is an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
    • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (>20% direct bilirubin) suggests a pathological cause (e.g., biliary atresia, neonatal hepatitis).

Key Takeaway

  • Breast milk jaundice is an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia seen in exclusively breastfed infants, persisting beyond 3-4 weeks but self-resolving without stopping breastfeeding.
  • Most cases do not require phototherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
• Choice B: "Delirium"
    • Delirium is NOT a feature of cystic fibrosis (CF).
    • CF primarily affects the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and endocrine systems, not the central nervous system.
    • Neurological symptoms like delirium are uncommon in CF unless secondary to severe systemic illness (e.g., sepsis, hypoxia).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: "Nasal polyps"
    • Correct feature - Nasal polyps are common in CF due to chronic sinusitis and inflammation.
    • Up to 50% of CF patients develop nasal polyps.
  • Choice C: "Meconium ileus"
    • Correct feature - Meconium ileus is a neonatal manifestation of CF.
    • It occurs in 10-20% of newborns with CF due to thickened intestinal secretions causing obstruction.
  • Choice D: "Bleeding diathesis"
    • Correct feature - CF patients can develop bleeding diathesis due to fat malabsorption and vitamin K deficiency, leading to coagulopathy.

Key Takeaway

  • Cystic fibrosis is a multi-system disorder primarily affecting the respiratory and gastrointestinal systems.
  • Neurological manifestations like delirium are not typical features.

questions.text: In a child with congenital heart disease, NADA's criteria includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
NADA's criteria for Congenital Heart Disease

Major

  • Systolic murmur grade Ill or more
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cyanosis
  • Congestive cardiac failure

Minor

  • Systolic murmur grade I or II
  • Abnormal second sound
  • Abnormal electrocardiogram
  • Abnormal X-ray
  • Abnormal blood pressure

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: "Diastolic murmur - Any grade"
    • Included in NADA's major criteria.
    • Diastolic murmurs are always considered pathological and indicate congenital heart disease.
  • Choice C: "Abnormal X-ray"
    • Included in NADA's minor criteria.
    • Chest X-ray may show cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion, or abnormal cardiac silhouettes in congenital heart disease.
  • Choice D: "Congestive cardiac failure"
    • Included in NADA's major criteria.
    • Signs of heart failure (tachypnea, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive) suggest significant congenital heart disease.

Key Takeaway

  • NADA's criteria help in the early detection of congenital heart disease based on clinical and radiological findings.
  • Troponin T is not included in these criteria.

choices.text: Areflexia of the affected limb is a mandatory diagnostic criteria
Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases
IVIG is the first line of treatment

questions.text: All of the following are true statements about Guillain-Barre syndrome except:
questions.solution:
• It is the most common cause of acute flaccid paralysis in children.
  • It is a rapidly progressive, predominantly motor, symmetric polyradiculoneuropathy that leads to bulbar and respiratory compromise.
  • The clinical features include acute onset of symmetrical ascending weakness that is both proximal and distal.
  • Dysautonomia is common and is suggested by tachycardia, arrhythmia, ileus, bladder dysfunction, labile blood pressure and impaired thermoregulation.
  • Features required for diagnosis
    • Progressive weakness in more than 1 limb (usually starts In legs)
    • Areflexia (or decreased tendon reflexes) In weak limbs
  • Immunotherapy is the mainstay of treatment. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG, 2 g/kg over 2-5 days) should be administered or plasma exchanges performed, if the child presents within 2-4 weeks of onset of symptoms. Such treatment is indicated in non-ambulatory patients, but their role in mobile, mildly affected patients is unclear.
  • CSF showing increased number of mononuclear cells (>50 cells/mm3) or polymorphonuclear cells.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: "Areflexia of the affected limb is a mandatory diagnostic criterion"
    • True statement → Areflexia (or reduced reflexes) in weak limbs is a required diagnostic feature of GBS.
    • The disease affects peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination and impaired reflexes.
  • Choice C: "IVIG is the first line of treatment"
    • True statement → IVIG is the first-line treatment in Guillain-Barre syndrome.
    • Given at 2 g/kg over 2-5 days, it helps reduce immune-mediated nerve damage.
  • Choice D: "Albumino-cytological dissociation CSF is characteristic"
    • True statement → Classic CSF finding in GBS is albumino-cytological dissociation (high protein with normal or low WBC count).
    • This occurs due to breakdown of the blood-nerve barrier without significant inflammation.

Key Takeaway

  • Plasmapheresis is an effective treatment, especially in refractory cases.
  • Areflexia, IVIG as first-line therapy, and albumino-cytological dissociation are all true statements.

questions.text: A four-year-old child was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of Croup is Parainfluenza virus type 1.
  • Most common cause of Laryngitis is H. Influenza type b.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: "Hemophilus influenzae"
    • Incorrect → H. influenzae type B is a major cause of epiglottitis, not croup.
    • Epiglottitis presents with high fever, drooling, and "tripod" positioning, unlike croup's barking cough and stridor.
  • Choice B: "Streptococcus pneumoniae"
    • Incorrect → S. pneumoniae causes bacterial pneumonia, otitis media, and sinusitis but is not a major cause of croup.
  • Choice D: "Diphtheria"
    • Incorrect → Diphtheria causes pseudomembranous pharyngitis, not croup.
    • It presents with grayish throat membrane, bull neck, and airway obstruction.

Key Takeaway

  • Most common cause of croup is Parainfluenza virus type 1, not Influenza virus.
  • Correct answer should be Parainfluenza virus type 1, but among the given options, Influenza virus (C) is the best choice.

choices.text: Increase in the pulmonary vascular resistance
Fall in the concentration of catecholamines

questions.text: Which of the following causes the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
• The increased oxygen saturation following birth causes the ductus arteriosus to constrict and close. Some functional patency and flow can be demonstrated through the ductus arteriosus for a few days after birth.
  • The ductus arteriosus closes anatomically within 10 to 21 days.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Decrease in CO2
    • CO2 levels do not directly regulate ductus arteriosus closure.
    • Oxygen, rather than CO2, plays the primary role in inducing closure.
  • Choice C: Increase in the pulmonary vascular resistance
    • At birth, pulmonary vascular resistance decreases, not increases.
    • This reduction allows for more blood flow through the lungs and is associated with ductal closure.
  • Choice D: Fall in the concentration of catecholamines
    • Catecholamines primarily assist in cardiovascular adaptations at birth but are not the main factor in ductus arteriosus closure.
    • Oxygen and prostaglandin regulation play a more significant role.

Key Takeaway

Increased oxygen levels after birth are the primary factor causing the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

choices.text: Chest compression at the rate of 30:2 with two rescuers
Adenosine is via intraosseous is preferred over other methods
In chest compression depth must be at least 1/3 of the AP diameter of the child's chest
Adrenaline is given in the dose of 0.01 mg/kg IV or IO in 1 in 1,000 concentration

questions.text: Which is a true statement regarding pediatric CPR?
questions.solution:
• Pediatric CPR guidelines recommend chest compressions at least 1/3 of the anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the chest.
  • This corresponds to approximately 5 inches (4 cm) in infants and 2 inches (5 cm) in children.

Explanation for other choices:

  • Choice A: Chest compression is at 15:2 with 2 rescuers and 30:2 with single rescuers.
  • Choice B: Adenosine is preferred intravenous over intraosseous.
  • Choice D: Adrenaline is given in dose of 0.01mg/kg IV or 1 in 10,000

Key Takeaway

Chest compressions in pediatric CPR should be at least 1/3 of the AP diameter of the chest to ensure effective circulation.

Reference: PALS guidelines, AAP, 2022
